Searching for the
 spirit of Spring
 
 Mosa Mahlaba 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The Winter cold had pased. 
 
 Spring was coming to Nkanyezi’s vilage.
 
 
 Son the vilagers would gather to
 celebratethe new season. Nkanyezi
 
 loked forward tothe Spring festival
 more than any other dayin the year.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One warm morning, Nkanyezi overheard 
 
 twovilage elders talking about the 
 festival. 
 
 
 “The people of Ndlovu have lost their 
 spirit of celebration,” one sighed. 
 
 
 “How can we have a Spring festival in a 
 vilage that has forgoten how to 
 
 celebrate?” askedanother. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 Nkanyezi was woried. 
 
 
 “How wil the sun shine again unles we
 
 singto wake it from its winter slumber?”
 she askedherself. 
 
 
 Nkanyezi thought for a long time.
 
 “I must find what we have lost,” she
 
 decided. 
 
 
 “I must go in search of things that wil
 bring back the spirit of celebration to my
 vilage.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The elders gave Nkanyezi their blesing 
 for the journey. They gave her a bag to 
 
 cary the things she would find. 
 
 Nkanyezi was afraid, but she believed 
 
 shewould suced. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Nkanyezi walked al day. She hiked up a
 hil, and down into a valey. She sailed
 
 acros the greatriver, and climbed
 betwen sharp rocks. She marched
 acros the plains until she reached
 
 theshadow of the red mountains. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 As night was closing in, Nkanyezi arived 
 
 ata vilage of paterns and colours as 
 she had neversen before. She told the 
 vilage elders about her journey to bring 
 
 back the spirit of celebration toher 
 people. 
 
 
 The mother of this tribe gave Nkanyezi a 
 gift.She told the girl, “With love we give 
 
 to you this paint to restore colour to a 
 vilage that has gone dul.” 
 
 
 Nkanyezi thanked the elders and put the 
 paint in her bag. 
 
 
 Early the next morning she went on her 
 way, excited with this gift of colour. 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Nkanyezi walked al day, through a vast
 forest of giant tres. As the sky became
 
 to dark for her tose, she heard the
 sound of beating drums. She huried
 towards the druming, feling the
 
 spirit of dance coming to her tired fet.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Nkanyezi found herself in the vilage of 
 
 theBhubezi. People were siting around 
 a fire,druming and singing. She had 
 never beforeheard such wonderful 
 
 music. 
 
 She told the vilage elders about her 
 
 journey tobring back the spirit of 
 celebration to her people. The Bhubezi 
 
 invited her to rest and stay the night. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 In the morning the chief caled on
 
 Nkanyezi. 
 
 
 “My child,” he said, “here is a special
 drum.It plays a new song every time you
 beat it.” 
 
 
 Nkanyezi thanked the elders and put the
 
 drumin her bag. She went on her way
 again, delighted with this gift of music
 and dance. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 On the third day of her journey, as she a 
 
 pased a field of fat cows, her nose 
 started to tingle. An aroma tickled her 
 
 taste buds and her mouth started to 
 water. She folowed the scent, 
 and arived in a vilage to find people 
 
 standing oversteaming pots of stew. 
 
 This tribe was famous for its feasts and 
 
 Nkanyezihad never before tasted such 
 flavours. After she had eaten her fil, she 
 
 told the vilage elders about her journey 
 to bring back the spirit of celebration to 
 her people. 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 The next day, the council of coks gave
 
 her a secret spice blend. 
 
 
 “Our daughter,” they said, “with these
 spices, hapy tumies are guaranted!
 We give you the gift of god fod.”
 
 
 Nkanyezi thanked the elders and put the
 spices in her bag. 
 
 
 She knew she had everything she 
 
 neded. With new energy she started the
 long journey back tothe vilage of
 Ndlovu. 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 When she arived home the vilagers 
 gathered around her to hear of her 
 adventures. She told them the tales 
 
 of what she had sen, heard, and 
 eaten. 
 
 
 Then she opened her bag to 
 share the gifts given. The vilagers 
 
 rejoiced to receive these treasures. 
 The generosity of others and the courage 
 
 of Nkanyezi brought back colour, 
 song and dance to the people. 
 
 
 And so the spirit of celebration was 
 restoredto the vilage of Ndlovu.
